libraries.name: The Myth Salon Library
libraries.subtitle: Mentone, Alabama
libraries.description: A living archive of mythological, spiritual, and cultural wisdom, devoted to preserving and sharing the world's deepest and most enduring stories. Located at the Mentone Mythouse Retreat in Alabama, the library is a sanctuary for rare texts, research collections, and curated works, including the revered Eranos Yearbooks.

shelves.name: Persian & Sufi Literature
shelves.description: The literary traditions of Iran and the Sufi mystics — from the national epic that preserved Persian identity after the Arab conquest, through the mystical poetry that remade the language of the divine across the Islamic world. These are not peripheral texts; the Shahnameh is the longest poem written by a single author in any language, and Rumi is the best-selling poet in America. The tradition runs from Zoroastrian scripture to ecstatic love poetry without ever losing the thread.

books.author: Zarathustra
books.title: Gathas (Hymns of Zarathustra)
books.note: The oldest hymns of the Avesta, composed by Zarathustra himself — among the oldest religious poetry on earth

books.title: Avesta
books.note: Liturgical collection: Yasna (worship), Yashts (hymns to individual yazatas), Vendidad (law), Visperad (extensions)

books.title: Bundahishn
books.note: Zoroastrian creation narrative: the cosmic battle, the primordial bull, the first man, the 12,000-year cycle

books.title: Denkard
books.note: Encyclopedia of Zoroastrian knowledge: theology, cosmology, history, ritual — the most comprehensive Pahlavi text

books.author: Ferdowsi
books.title: Shahnameh (Book of Kings)

books.author: Farid ud-Din Attar
books.title: The Conference of the Birds (Manteq al-Tayr)
books.note: Thirty birds journey through seven valleys to find the Simorgh — and discover they are the Simorgh (si morgh = thirty birds)

books.author: Rumi (Jalal ad-Din Muhammad Balkhi)
books.title: Masnavi-ye-Ma'navi

books.author: Rumi

books.author: Hafez (Khwaja Shams-ud-Din Muhammad)

books.author: Saadi

shelves.name: The Chronosphaera
shelves.description: The complete lineage of the seven-planet tradition — from Sumerian astronomers who first named the wandering stars, through Hermetic mages, Islamic polymaths, Renaissance synthesists, and modern Theosophists, to the channeled cosmologies of the twentieth century. Every text that contributed a layer to the system of planetary correspondences: day, hour, metal, deity, chakra, virtue, vice, and tone.

books.title: Sumerian Star Catalogs and Temple Hymns
books.note: Earliest planetary identifications; includes hymns of Enheduanna (c. 2285 BCE), first named author in history

books.title: Enūma Anu Enlil
books.note: Omen series codifying planet–god associations: Shamash, Sin, Nergal, Nabu, Ishtar, Marduk, Ninurta

books.title: Ugaritic Texts (Ras Shamra)
books.note: El–Saturn and Astarte–Venus among the earliest attested planet–deity pairings outside Mesopotamia

books.title: Enūma Eliš
books.note: Creation epic; Marduk's victory orders the cosmos and assigns the stations of the planets

books.title: MUL.APIN
books.note: Earliest systematic star and planet catalogue; establishes the 7 wanderers and the Chaldean order by orbital period

books.title: Ashurbanipal's Library Tablets
books.note: Neo-Assyrian metal-planet tablets; Mars-iron military association; Saros cycle and lunar eclipse prediction

books.title: Genesis 1:1–2:3
books.note: Seven days of creation; assigns no planets or metals — those layers arrive through Kabbalah and alchemy

books.author: Plato
books.title: Timaeus
books.note: Seven planetary spheres as cosmic architecture; each sphere a soul producing a tone; foundation for the music of the spheres

books.title: Sefer Yetzirah
books.note: Book of Formation; Hebrew letters, numbers, and elements as creative forces; earliest Kabbalistic planetary mapping

books.author: Nicomachus of Gerasa
books.title: Introduction to Arithmetic
books.note: Pythagorean numerical archetypes; planetary harmony as mathematical proportion

books.title: Corpus Hermeticum (Poimandres)
books.note: Seven governors of destiny; the soul descends through planetary spheres acquiring qualities at each level

books.author: Ptolemy
books.title: Tetrabiblos
books.note: Definitive astrological system; four qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry); essential dignities, day/night sect

books.author: Vettius Valens
books.title: Anthologiae
books.note: Earliest explicit description of planetary hours — the key mechanism linking the Chaldean order to weekday names

books.title: Apocryphon of John
books.note: Seven archons as planetary rulers; the soul's ascent through hostile spheres requiring passwords at each gate

books.author: Cassius Dio
books.title: Roman History, Book 37
books.note: Explains why days follow Sun–Moon–Mars–Mercury–Jupiter–Venus–Saturn rather than the Chaldean sequence

books.author: Origen
books.title: Contra Celsum
books.note: Preserves the Ophite seven-archon system and Mithraic planetary ladder of initiation (via Celsus, c. 175 CE)

books.author: Plotinus
books.title: Enneads
books.note: Emanation from the One through Nous and World-Soul; planetary spheres as stages of descent and return

books.author: Iamblichus
books.title: De Mysteriis
books.note: Theurgic ritual and planetary invocation; defense of embodied spiritual practice against Porphyry's intellectualism

books.title: Felicissimus Mithraeum Mosaic
books.note: Seven initiation grades mapped to planets: Corax–Mercury, Nymphus–Venus, Miles–Mars, Leo–Jupiter, Perses–Moon, Heliodromus–Sun, Pater–Saturn

books.author: Macrobius
books.title: Commentary on the Dream of Scipio
books.note: Preserves the Chaldean order; music of the spheres; transmitted the planetary tradition to the medieval Latin West

books.title: Surya Siddhanta
books.note: Indian astronomical treatise; Navagraha planetary system with Jyotish dignities and periods

books.author: Isidore of Seville
books.title: Etymologiae
books.note: Names each weekday after its ruling planet; the standard reference of the medieval Latin West

books.title: Brihat Parashara Hora Shastra
books.note: Foundation of Vedic astrology; planetary rulerships, dignities, and dasha periods

books.author: Bede
books.title: De Temporum Ratione

books.author: Abu Ma'shar (Albumasar)
books.title: Kitab al-Madkhal al-Kabir

books.author: Al-Farabi
books.title: Ara Ahl al-Madina al-Fadila (The Virtuous City)

books.title: Rasa'il Ikhwan al-Safa

books.title: Picatrix (Ghayat al-Hakim)

books.author: Al-Biruni
books.title: The Chronology of Ancient Nations

books.author: Al-Biruni
books.title: Kitab al-Tafhim

books.author: Snorri Sturluson

books.title: Zohar

books.author: Dante Alighieri

books.author: Marsilio Ficino

books.author: Paracelsus

books.author: John Dee

books.author: William Lilly

works.creator: Richard Strauss
works.title: Also Sprach Zarathustra
works.note: After Nietzsche; iconic in 2001: A Space Odyssey

libraries.name: Library of Alexandria
libraries.subtitle: Alexandria, Egypt
libraries.description: The greatest repository of knowledge in the classical world. Founded under Ptolemy I Soter in the 3rd century BCE, it held hundreds of thousands of scrolls spanning philosophy, science, literature, and theology.

shelves.name: Notable Scrolls & Works
shelves.description: Texts written, copied, studied, or housed within the walls of the Great Library.

books.author: Euclid
books.title: Elements
books.note: The foundational treatise on geometry, written in Alexandria; the most republished mathematics text in history.

books.author: Eratosthenes
books.title: Geographica
books.note: Calculated the circumference of the Earth using shadow angles between Alexandria and Syene.

books.author: Callimachus
books.title: Pinakes
books.note: The first known library catalog — 120 scrolls classifying the entire collection of the Great Library.

books.author: Apollonius of Rhodes
books.title: Argonautica
books.note: Epic poem of Jason and the Argonauts, composed while Apollonius served as head librarian.

books.author: Aristarchus of Samothrace
books.title: Critical Editions of Homer
books.note: Established the scholarly method of textual criticism; his recension of the Iliad and Odyssey became the standard.

books.author: Hero of Alexandria
books.title: Pneumatica
books.note: Described the aeolipile (proto-steam engine), automata, and pneumatic devices — engineering centuries ahead of its time.

books.author: Claudius Ptolemy
books.title: Almagest
books.note: The definitive astronomical treatise of antiquity; geocentric model that dominated for 1,400 years.

books.author: Claudius Ptolemy
books.title: Geographia
books.note: Mapped the known world with coordinates for 8,000 locations; used until the Age of Exploration.

books.author: Archimedes
books.title: On Floating Bodies
books.note: Foundational work on hydrostatics. Archimedes corresponded with Alexandrian scholars; copies preserved in the Library.

books.author: Hipparchus
books.title: Star Catalogue
books.note: Catalogued ~850 stars with positions and magnitudes; discovered the precession of the equinoxes.

books.author: Diophantus
books.title: Arithmetica
books.note: Father of algebra. His work on number theory inspired Fermat's Last Theorem sixteen centuries later.

books.author: Hypatia
books.title: Commentary on the Arithmetica of Diophantus
books.note: Alexandrian philosopher and mathematician — the last great scholar of the ancient Library tradition.
